utterances: What I saw on my three trips to Iraq - 2004, 2005 and 2006 - was Marines doing the best that they could to try and execute their security and stability mission, but really in kind of a policy and strategy vacuum.
What I hear now back in the States is a little bit disconcerting.
It sort of amounts to, kind of, moving the goal posts to fight, you know, the goal posts are sort of imminently portable.
So now, we focus on, you know, very important things - decrease in civilian casualties, decrease in U.S.
military casualties.

But it seems that some of the more - sort of a long-term metrics that the administration was talking about -political reconciliation, you know, the nuts and bolts things like increasing electricity production, oil production, you know, keeping the price of food low, limiting inflation, that sort of stuff had gone by the wayside.
Do the Marines ever talk about that or do they just say, you know what, I'm here to do my job and I can't be worried about those people in Washington?
Oh, I have get to rid of all my gift bags now and start wrapping.
Professional gift wrapper Mia Canada of Atlanta, Ga.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""PRESENTS FOR CHRISTMAS"")
Well, they are very close.
Right now, Charlie Cook said there were 90 Democratic districts in jeopardy.

Now, even if Republicans only win half that, or the Democrats only lose half that, that's still 45 -because math was always my forte - and so 45 is enough to give the Republicans the majority in the House.
Nate Silver of the New York Times does the 538 blog, says that up to 50 seats are in jeopardy.
Now, that's an unusual number, but we've seen it before.
The Republicans picked up 52 seats in 1994.
It's doable, but that would be something.
In the Senate they would need 10 seats to take over control of the United States Senate.
Again, what does that look...
They need 10, and there are some numbers that are looking a little bit better for the Democrats.
Barbara Boxer seems to have a solid, even though a narrow, lead in California.
But again, in Wisconsin, that's not looking great for Russ Feingold.
He is trailing in almost every poll.
In Nevada, they just showed that Sharron Angle's raised $14 million in the past quarter, and polls still show her dead even with Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader.
Still, the Democrats were worried in Delaware, maybe worried in Connecticut.
It looks like they may not have to worry so much.
That's correct.
Christine O'Donnell has made the Democrats' task much easier in Delaware, Chris Coons likely to win that.
He's up by anywhere between 17 and 20 points in most polls.
And while Linda McMahon, the former wrestling executive in Connecticut, has spent some $20 million of her own money, she's still trailing to Richard Blumenthal.
And let's go to some people who think they know the answer to this week's trivia question.
Again, we're going to try to make it simple this week.
If you think you know someone who has, in the last 30 years or so, been elected governor, senator and governor, email us...
And senator.
That's right.
Email talk@npr.org.
And we'll start with Will, and Will's calling us from Florence in South Carolina.
Hey, I'm not sure if it's right because I'm not sure if he was ever a mayor, but I know Strom Thurmond served as a senator and governor of South Carolina.
You are correct.
He served as senator and governor, and you were correct.
He never served as mayor.
So you are incorrect, sir.
Thanks very much for the phone call.
Let's go instead to Matthew, and Matthew with us from Big Stone Gap in Virginia.
Hello.
My guess was Mark Warner.
Mark Warner, the - well, certainly former senator.
And, well, he's a senator.
He's a current senator and former governor.
But like Strom Thurmond - and a lot of people confuse Mark Warner and Strom Thurmond - but neither served in the House - neither served as mayor, I'm sorry.
Excuse me.
So thanks very much for the call, Matthew.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Let's see if we can go next to Mary Ellen(ph), Mary Ellen in Cleveland.
Hi, is it George Voinovich?
Well...
(Soundbite of laughter)
I started off the question, George Voinovich has served in all three, name somebody else.
So...
So yes and no.
Okay.
Thanks very much, and let's go to - this is Marika(ph), Marika with us from Buffalo.
Yes, I think it's Pete Wilson from California.
Pete Wilson is a correct answer.
Woo-hoo!
Pete Wilson, a former governor, former senator and also the former mayor of San Diego.
By the way, just in case anybody cares, two other people I thought of: Dirk Kempthorne.

But Pete Wilson...
And there might be some others as well.
No, I can't think of any.

But anyway, Pete Wilson is a correct answer.
Marika, we're going to put you on hold and collect your particulars.
